abstract.text: Add and configure an extension to enable your location-sharing app to access a user’s location in response to a request from another user.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Creating a location push service extension

inlineContent.text: The Location Push Service Extension, available starting in iOS 15, is a power efficient way to query locations on iOS or iPadOS devices, even when your app isn’t running.
When your app includes a Location Push Service Extension, the system activates the extension when it receives an Apple Push Notification service (APNs)
push from your server. Your app must ask for and receive Always authorization (
) from the user before the extension can function. For more information about requesting Always authorization, see
and
With the user’s authorization, the extension can query the user’s location and process it according to your app’s purpose. Your server sends requests with the
push type to APNs. For more information about sending requests to APNs, see
To use the Location Push Service Extension, your app must have the
entitlement. Request this entitlement before implementing this service extension. To apply for the entitlement, log in to your developer account with an Account Holder role and fill out the
To include Location Push Service Extension in your app, use Xcode 13 or later. Configure the following entitlements, capabilities, and keys for your Xcode project:
Set the Location Push Server Extension entitlement key (
Enable your app to receive Apple Push Notification service (APNs) pushes by adding the Push Notifications capability. For more information, see
Configure the purpose strings your app provides for the location service authorization prompts. For more information, see

content.text: Add a Location Push Service Extension Target

inlineContent.text: Add a new target using the Location Push Service Extension template.
Open your iOS app project in Xcode.
Choose File > New > Target.
Select Location Push Service Extension from the iOS Application Extension group.
Click Next.
Specify the name of your extension and configure the language and other options.
Click Finish.
Xcode creates a subclass of
to get you started.
To support location push functionality, implement the following code in your extension, app, and server:
In your service extension, implement the
protocol.
In your service extension, implement the
method to handle the result of the location request, and process the location data received.
In your app, call
to receive an APNs token as
, and send it to your server. Your server uses this token when it creates APNs pushes.
From your server, request location information by sending a
push request to APNs.
If the user authorized your app with Always authorization (
), the system activates the service extension when it receives a
push, and calls
. Your app should ask the user for Always authorization at an appropriate time.

Protecting user privacy is important when handling location data. End-to-end encryption provides enhanced security if your app moves location data off the user’s device, including transmitting it to a server or to another user. For more information, see

content.text: Send Location Push Requests From Your Server

inlineContent.text: When a user requests the location of another user, your app sends the request to your server, which sends a location push request to APNs. Ensure that your APNs
request contains the following fields for a
push type:
(Required) The value is
(Required) The path to the device token. The value of this header is
, where
is the hexadecimal identifier of the user’s device. Your app receives the token when it calls
to start monitoring location pushes.
(Required for token-based authentication) The value of this header is
, where
is the encrypted token that authorizes you to send notifications for the specified topic. For more information, see
The topic is your app’s bundle ID with the suffix
(Recommended) The value of this header is
The priority of the notification. If you omit this header, APNs sets the notification priority to
. If a user initiates the location query, set this header to
. If your app’s server initiates the location query (for example, on a periodic interval) set this header to
to send the notification based on power considerations on the user’s device.
For more information about sending APNs requests and using command-line tools to do so, see
and

abstract.text: Obtain the geographic location and orientation of a device.
The user authorized the app to start location services at any time.
The floor of a building on which the user’s device is located.
The latitude, longitude, and course information reported by the system.
The latitude and longitude associated with a location, specified using the WGS 84 reference frame.
Requests the user’s permission to use location services regardless of whether the app is in use.
Starts monitoring for the delivery of Apple Push Notification service (APNs) location pushes, and provides a device-specific token for sending pushes.
Tells the delegate that new location data is available.
The interface you adopt in the type that acts as the main entry point for a Location Push Service Extension.
Delivers a location push notification for your app extension to process.
Information about the source that provides a location.
An object that provides device location updates.
Information about the user’s location during a specific period of time.
Start location services and provide information the system needs to optimize power usage for those services.

abstract.text: An entitlement to enable a location-sharing app to query someone’s location in response to a push notification.
Secure personal data, and respect user preferences for how data is used.
Secure your communications with Apple Push Notification service (APNs) by using stateless authentication tokens.

abstract.text: Communicate with Apple Push Notification service (APNs) and receive a unique device token that identifies your app.
Transmit your remote notification payload and device token information to Apple Push Notification service (APNs).
Use basic macOS command-line tools to send push notifications to Apple Push Notification service (APNs).
